conclusion: Understanding the circuit problem with a battery, resistances, a voltmeter, and a switch.
Need to find the voltage between points a and b when the switch is closed.
Circuit has a 10-ohm and a 20-ohm resistor in parallel between points a and b, with a voltmeter across the 20-ohm resistor.
Battery has an emf ε and an internal resistance r, with another resistance R in series.
Battery is connected between points a and b through resistance R and internal resistance r.
Switch S is in parallel with the 10-ohm resistor and the battery branch.
Point a is connected to a 10-ohm resistor in parallel with switch S.
Switch S is connected to the battery ε in series with internal resistance r and resistance R.
Battery branch is connected to point b.
20-ohm resistor is connected between points a and b.
Voltmeter is connected across the 20-ohm resistor.
Voltmeter reads 6V when switch S is open.
With S open, the 10-ohm resistor is not connected; circuit is battery ε in series with r and R connected between a and b.
Voltage across a and b is equal to the voltage across the 20-ohm resistor, which is 6V.
When S is open, the only path from a to b is through the battery, R, and the 20-ohm resistor.
Voltage across a and b is 6V when S is open.
When S is closed, it provides another path from a to b through the 10-ohm resistor in parallel.
Two parallel paths from a to b: through R and r, then the 20-ohm resistor, and through the 10-ohm resistor.
Need to find the equivalent resistance and see how the currents divide when S is closed.
20-ohm resistor is connected directly from a to b, and the voltmeter is across it.
